item.title: When Does The Battlefield 6 Beta End? Open Beta End Times Explained
item.content:encoded:
The first Battlefield 6 open beta has ended after an intense weekend of record-breaking action, but that‚Äôs not the end of the line for the game. Electronic Arts has lined up a second test that‚Äôll come later this week, but when does the Battlefield 6 beta end for good? And when it does, what are your options?

Read on to learn everything you need to know about the Battlefield 6 beta end times and where it goes from there.

Battlefield 6 Beta End Times

The next Battlefield 6 open beta is scheduled to run from August 14 (08:00 UTC) to August 18 (08:00 UTC). That means the end time for the next Battlefield 6 open beta is at 01:00 PT / 04:00 AM ET on August 18. You‚Äôll get an entire four-day window to play Battlefield 6, but it could be your last chance until the game comes out on October 10.

That brings me to your options going forward.

Once you‚Äôve enjoyed the Battlefield 6 beta, you‚Äôre free to sit back and wait until October to get your hands on the full game, or you can try your luck with Battlefield Labs, which should reopen following the end of the Battlefield 6 beta.

Here‚Äôs a guide explaining how to get into Battlefield Labs.

The Battlefield 6 beta went nuts during the first weekend of play, with more than 500,000 players joining the fun on Steam alone. It skyrocketed on platforms like Twitch, hitting almost 900,000 concurrent viewers, far more than any Call of Duty game (except Warzone) has ever managed.

The second round of the Battlefield 6 beta isn‚Äôt expected to be any different from the first, but feedback gathered during the opening window will help shape some of the balancing tactics going into the second stage.

item.title: BioWare Wanted a Dragon Age Trilogy Remaster But EA Wouldn‚Äôt Fund It
item.content:encoded:
Dragon Age, like Mass Effect, didn‚Äôt have the best time when its most recent title was released. In October 2024, BioWare and Electronic Arts dropped Dragon Age: Veilguard, which wasn‚Äôt well received by audiences, much like 2017‚Äôs Mass Effect: Andromeda. However, Mass Effect has an advantage over Dragon Age in that the series boasts a trilogy remaster.

When recently challenged on why Dragon Age doesn‚Äôt have a trilogy remaster, or a ‚ÄòLegendary Edition‚Äô, former BioWare executive producer of more than 20 years, Mark Darrah, explained what‚Äôs up.

‚ÄòDo It With The Money You Have‚Äô

Mark Darrah departed BioWare in 2022 after spending 24 years rising through the ranks at the company. He saw some of the most popular games of certain eras go out the doors at BioWare, including the Mass Effect ‚Äòquadrilogy‚Äô and every Dragon Age game bar last year‚Äôs Veilguard.

In a recent interview with MrMattyPlays, Darrah got onto the topic of a Dragon Age trilogy remaster (not remake) in the vein of the Mass Effect Legendary Edition, explaining why it probably won‚Äôt ever be a thing:

I honestly think they should do ‚Äì I don‚Äôt think they will ‚Äì but I think they should do a remaster of the first three. One of the things we pitched at one point, pretty softly, was to retroactively rebrand the first three games as if they were a trilogy and call it the Champion‚Äôs Trilogy.

Maybe you do that, and as a first step, you take those three games (and maybe Veilguard), you shine them up, you re-release them, probably remaster, not a remake, see what happens, and then maybe go from there.

Darrah highlighted the stark similarities between the ‚Äòstates‚Äô of the Mass Effect franchise and the Dragon Age franchise, but admitted that the latter is much harder to remaster than the former. Not only that, but there‚Äôs no money coming from EA to support the idea:

EA has said this publically, they‚Äôre kind of against remasters. I don‚Äôt really know why, it‚Äôs strange for a publically-traded company to seem to be against free money, but they seem to be against it, so that‚Äôs part of it.

The other problem is that Dragon Age is harder than Mass Effect to do.

One of the earliest things was, let‚Äôs do Frostbite Tools, and then let‚Äôs find a mod house that seems talented and just uplift them and pay them to do a remake of Dragon Age Origins.

There were lots of pitches around it, is there a way we can bring Dragon Age Origins forward?

The studios ruin their financials within themselves. I think, to some degree, EA‚Äôs stance was, ‚ÄòSure, go ahead and do it, but do it with the money you already have.‚Äô We couldn‚Äôt do it with the money that we already have, because we‚Äôre doing all these other things.

The full interview can be seen here:

Dragon Age: Veilguard scored well in the review stakes when it was released last year, but failed to resonate with the general audience, as reflected in its low aggregate scores on platforms like Steam.

item.title: Player Spends $32,000 on NBA 2K25 in Just Five Months
item.content:encoded:
One player has gone viral for spending an astonishing $32,000 in NBA 2K25 in just five months on microtransactions.

The clip was posted to X, which showed YouTube 2KOG going through his microtransaction purchases for NBA 2K25 on the PlayStation Store, where he revealed that he‚Äôs spent an astonishing $32,831.68 on the game.

The clip reveals that transactions started on March 31, 2025, and ended on August 5, 2025, the date the clip was recorded. All of the transactions are for the game‚Äôs Virtual Currency Pack, with the highest costing $160.48 each.

You can watch the full clip below:

The YouTuber himself revealed that he‚Äôs learned his lesson from spending such a large amount of money, and warned others that it‚Äôs not worth chasing cards or spending large amounts of money for content creation.

What‚Äôs worse is that despite him spending $32,000, he‚Äôs still not obtained all of the best cards in the game. In fact, just by watching his video, he would probably need to spend an equal amount of money to get near completion.

‚ÄúOne things for sure, I will not spend this much again, because you don‚Äôt get rewarded for it. As much as I spent, I should have everything in the game, but it‚Äôs not even close,‚Äù he said.

NBA 2K26 also releases on Setpember 5, 2025, which will make all of his purchases pretty useless if he was to move on to the next game.

item.title: Battlefield‚Äôs ‚ÄòBiggest Open Beta Ever‚Äô is Celebrated as Success Continues
item.content:encoded:
Last night, the Battlefield 6 open beta hit more than 500,000 concurrent players on Steam alone. It shattered records held by Call of Duty and pushed past 850,000 peak viewers on Twitch, widely representing the fact that Battlefield is back.

In a post on social media, the Battlefield team reiterated that this is the largest open beta in Battlefield history, as if we didn‚Äôt already know that. The hype is skyrocketing, the excitement is at unprecedented levels, and the future of Battlefield is (finally) looking bright.

Peak Times

In a post on social media, EA‚Äôs Battlefield Comms team wrote:

This is Battlefield‚Äôs biggest Open Beta ever.

Peak time is approaching and queues will be expected. We‚Äôre working on entry times to the game, but appreciate your patience as you wait for your time to arrive.

We want everyone to experience a smooth and fair Open Beta, including those currently within the game too.

Thank you for your continued excitement for Battlefield 6‚Äôs Open Beta!

Even issues with Battlefield 6‚Äôs first cheaters haven‚Äôt hampered the fun too much. The Javelin anti-cheat engine is doing a great job at nipping that in the bud, with almost half a million attempts at cheating being caught by the system. Some will inevitably get through, but after many hours in the beta, I‚Äôm happy to say I‚Äôve seen no suspicious behaviour.

Battlefield 6 is set to drop on October 10, which could be mere weeks before the launch of Call of Duty: Black Ops 7. The performance of the beta has given fans a renewed sense of adoration for the series, and there‚Äôs now a hope that this will be the year that Battlefield batters Call of Duty in the leaderboard stakes.

item.title: Far Cry TV Show Reveal Appears on Ubisoft‚Äôs Site, is Quickly Removed Again
item.content:encoded:
Someone at Ubisoft might have made a boo-boo by posting early about a Far Cry television series reportedly in development at FX. Eagle-eyed users spotted the post on the Ubisoft site and relayed it across social media, but the article was quickly removed and the link set to redirect to the site‚Äôs home page.

They weren‚Äôt fast enough for the avid internet users who captured snippets of the post, revealing some cast and crew information and a lowdown on the show‚Äôs envisioned season structure.

‚ÄòDarkest and Most Absurd‚Äô

Far Cry is a legendary series from Ubisoft, but it has been a fair few years since the series has had any time in the spotlight. Far Cry 6 emerged in 2021 and became regarded as one of the worst games in franchise history, so it seems Ubisoft is eager to take a little extra time finessing Far Cry 7 (or whatever it‚Äôll be called).

In a recent post on Ubisoft‚Äôs news site, it was revealed (potentially prematurely) that a Far Cry TV show is in production at FX. The post has now been removed, but not before users could capture and share information on Reddit:

Mac (It‚Äôs Always Sunny in Philadelphia, Mythic Quest, Welcome to Wrexham) and Hawley (Fargo, Alien: Earth) are the co-creators of the Far Cry series. Hawley will also serve as showrunner, while Mac is set to star in the show. The series will be executive produced by Mac, Hawley, and Jackie Cohn for More Better Productions; Michael Garcia for 26Keys Productions; Nick Frenkel for 3Arts Entertainment; and Gerard Guillemot, Margaret Boykin, and Austin Dill for Ubisoft Film & Television.

‚ÄúThis collaboration is really an embarrassment of riches. Far Cry a psychological tailspin that doesn‚Äôt shy away from the darkest and most absurd parts of humanity, which aligns perfectly with FX‚Äôs bold and fearless storytelling style,‚Äù said Margaret Boykin, head of film and television content, Ubisoft Film & Television.

It‚Äôs worth pointing out that while the article was deleted, the slug remains:

far-cry-series-adaptation-in-the-works-at-fx

That tells you all you need to know.

One of the most recent Far Cry stories to drop exclusively here at Insider Gaming concerned the extraction-based multiplayer shooter that‚Äôs in development at Ubisoft with the Far Cry name attached to it. In March, our Tom Henderson revealed the game had been rebooted internally.

item.title: Battlefield 6 Open Beta Hits 500,000 Concurrent Players on Steam and Passes Call of Duty All-Time High
item.content:encoded:
Battlefield 6 has smashed past the 500,000 concurrent player mark on Steam, surpassing Call of Duty‚Äôs all-time high of 491,670.

The milestone was hit just minutes ago as the game sees its first Open Beta date kick off today (the past two days were a closed Beta period with limited access).

While the comparison against Call of Duty is somewhat unfair, it‚Äôs worth noting that Battlefield 6 is in an Open Beta period, and its concurrent player count success does not reflect how many people will buy the game when it launches on October 10, 2025.

However, the game has smashed past Call of Duty‚Äôs all-time high for Steam, which includes the highly popular and free-to-play Call of Duty: Warzone and any betas that have taken place over the past couple of years.

Earlier this week, Insider Gaming reported that Activision executives were not worried about Battlefield 6‚Äôs success because Call of Duty is ‚Äútoo big to fail‚Äù. But perhaps the recent success has had executives rethinking that thought.

Of course, Call of Duty will remain one of the highest-selling games each consecutive year, but there has to be some props given to EA and Battlefield Studios for turning around the franchise.

You can watch the Battlefield 6 concurrent player count chart on SteamDB here.

Battlefield 6 launches on the PlayStation 5, Xbox Series S|X, and PC on October 10, 2025.

item.title: EXCLUSIVE: Sentinels CEO Says Marvel Rivals Team Bundles Are ‚ÄòCritical‚Äô For Esports Future
item.content:encoded:
Sentinels CEO Rob Moore believes the introduction of team bundles to Marvel Rivals is ‚Äúcritical‚Äù for the future of the game in the Esports scene.

Still in its infancy, Marvel Rivals has created a storm on the Esports front, luring big names to make the jump from Overwatch. Other pros have been attracted from the likes of Fortnite and Halo.

An impressive showcase at the Marvel Rivals Ignite Mid-Season Finals in Guangzhou is evidence that NetEase holds the cards required to become a mainstay on the scene. However, speaking exclusively to Insider Gaming at the event, Moore is adamant the next step must be team bundles and skins.

Marvel Rivals Open To Team Bundles Being Added

‚ÄúThe real key is what happens next. In terms of skins that are part of the game for tournaments, or something to continue to reward the investment in the game.

‚ÄúThat is a critical element of having organisations continuing to invest, showing that support. I think that‚Äôs the one key additional step that needs to take place.‚Äù

Moore confirmed that no talks between Sentinels and the Marvel Rivals team have taken place yet for such an addition, though he hopes it is a ‚Äúpriority‚Äù and pointed to other Esports that have introduced those items as ‚Äúreally having helped the economics of the game.‚Äù

Although there is no concrete news on whether team bundles or the like will be added to Marvel Rivals, Esports Tournament lead Adam Huang confirmed to Jake Lucky that they need to be considered and more needs to be offered to teams beyond the initial prize pools up for grabs.

While Moore is hopeful more will be offered by Marvel Rivals in the future, he was clear in his praise for the efforts so far and the quick impact that NetEase has made on the Esports scene.

‚ÄúAs an organisation, we really try to prioritize getting into new games that have a lot of growth, and we saw this early, it took off. We had the opportunity to be one of the first brands in the game.

‚ÄúNetease has made a real commitment to the esports game and really supported it, you can see with what they have put on, bringing in all the teams early so they can boot camp. All in all, it‚Äôs been a really good event considering it‚Äôs the first they‚Äôve put on.‚Äù

Next Marvel Rivals Finals Will Be ‚ÄòBigger & Better‚Äô

Next on the agenda for Marvel Rivals‚Äô Esports scene is Stage 2 of the Ignite Regionals, culminating in the Grand Finals later this year. Speaking to Insider Gaming, game director Guangguang outlined his hope that tournament, which could take place outside of China, will be ‚Äúbigger and better.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe are so glad to see many professional teams and media friends joining the tournament. This is our first time holding an offline tournament like this, so we‚Äôre feeling the challenge.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre working very hard and focusing our effort on making a better game to see players enjoy themselves.

‚ÄúThis offline tournament is a different environment from the in-game environment, so we will try to make the finals bigger and better.‚Äù

Is Marvel Rivals here to stay on the Esports scene? Let us know your thoughts in the Insider Gaming forum.
